## Decree-by-Law No. 84 of 2025
### Regarding the Approval of an Agreement
### Between the Government of the State of Kuwait
### and the Government of the Republic of San Marino
### for the Encouragement and Reciprocal Protection of Investments

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And upon the proposal of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And with the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
- We have issued the following Decree-by-Law:

### Article One
The Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of San Marino for the Encouragement and Reciprocal Protection of Investments, signed in New York City on 27/9/2024, the text of which is attached to this Decree-by-Law, is hereby approved.

## Explanatory Memorandum
### To Decree-Law No. 84 of 2025
### Approving the Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>حكومة دولة الكويت</orig>
### and the Government of the Republic of San Marino <orig>حكومة جمهورية سان مارينو</orig>
### for the Encouragement and Reciprocal Protection of Investments

Desiring to encourage economic cooperation with respect to investment by nationals and legal entities of one Contracting Party in the territory of the other Contracting Party, as well as to achieve healthy, stable, and sustainable economic development.
An agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>حكومة دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Republic of San Marino <orig>حكومة جمهورية سان مارينو</orig> for the Encouragement and Reciprocal Protection of Investments was signed on 27/9/2024 in the city of New York.
This agreement addressed in Article (1) definitions and terms, and in Article (2) the encouragement, admission, and protection of investments, stipulating that each Contracting Party shall encourage and create more favorable conditions for investments made by investors of the other Contracting Party in its territory.
Article (3) stipulated National Treatment, whereby each Contracting Party shall grant to investors of the other Contracting Party treatment no less favorable than that which it accords in like circumstances to its own investors with respect to the establishment, acquisition, expansion, management, operation, or sale. Article (4) addressed Most-Favored-Nation Treatment.
Article (5) provided for compensation for losses when investments made by investors of either Contracting Party suffer losses due to war or other conflicts or civil disturbances. Article (6) dealt with expropriation, and Article (7) stipulated transfers, ensuring that each Contracting Party guarantees that all payments related to an investment in its territory by an investor of the other Contracting Party shall be freely transferable into and out of its territory without delay. Article (8) addressed subrogation, and Article (9) provided for the settlement of disputes between a Contracting Party and an investor of the other Contracting Party, stating that they shall be settled amicably through negotiations.
Article (10) specified the settlement of disputes between the Contracting Parties, stating that disputes between the Contracting Parties shall be resolved through diplomatic channels. Article (11) provided for the application of other provisions, and Article (12) addressed the scope of the agreement, stipulating that it shall apply to all investments, whether existing before or after the date of entry into force of this agreement.
Article (13) stipulated the relations between the Contracting Parties, stating that the provisions of this agreement shall apply regardless of the existence of diplomatic or consular relations. Article (14) addressed the entry into force of the agreement, whereby it shall enter into force on the thirtieth day after the date of receipt of the last of the two notifications from the parties

Whereas this Agreement serves the interest of Kuwait and does not conflict with its commitments in the Arab and international spheres, and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزارة الخارجية</orig> has requested the preparation of the necessary legal instrument for ratification.
And whereas this Agreement is considered one of the agreements mentioned in the second paragraph of Article (70) of the Constitution, and therefore its approval must be by law in accordance with the provision of this paragraph, and based on Article Four of the Amiri Order issued on 10/5/2024, which stipulated that laws shall be issued by decree-laws, a draft decree-law has therefore been prepared for the approval of this Agreement.
Its first article stipulated the approval of the aforementioned Agreement, and its second article obligates the ministers, each within their respective jurisdictions, to implement this decree-law, and that it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

# Agreement
Between the Government of the State of Kuwait
and the Government of the Republic of San Marino
for the Promotion and Protection of Mutual Investments

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of San Marino, hereinafter referred to as the "Contracting Parties".
Desiring to encourage greater economic cooperation between them with respect to investment by nationals and legal entities of one Contracting Party in the territory of the other Contracting Party, as well as to achieve healthy, stable, and sustainable economic development,
Recognizing that an agreement on the treatment to be accorded to such investments will stimulate the flow of private capital and the economic development of the Contracting Parties;
Agreeing that a stable framework for investment will maximize the effective utilization of economic resources and improve living standards;
Having resolved to conclude an agreement for the promotion and protection of mutual investments, have agreed as follows:

## Article 1
Definitions

For the purposes of this Agreement:
1. The term "investment" means every kind of right or asset invested by an investor of a Contracting Party in the territory of the other Contracting Party, owned or controlled directly or indirectly, and includes in particular, but not exclusively:
   (a) shares, stocks, and other forms of equity participation in companies, loans, and securities issued by any investor of a Contracting Party;
   (b) claims to money or to any contractual performance having an economic value;
   (c) intellectual property rights, including but not limited to, copyrights, trademarks, patents, industrial designs and models, technical processes, know-how, trade secrets, trade names, and goodwill;
   (d) any right conferred by law, or contract, or by virtue of any licenses, or permits granted pursuant to law, including rights to exploration, extraction, or exploitation of natural resources;
   (e) any tangible or intangible, movable or immovable property and any related property rights, such as leases, mortgages, liens, pledges, and similar rights;
   (f) "returns" retained for the purpose of reinvestment and proceeds from "liquidation".
   Any change in the form in which assets or rights are invested or reinvested shall not affect their character as investments.
2. The term "investor" means:
   (a) With respect to the State of Kuwait:
      (1) a natural person holding the nationality of the State of Kuwait in accordance with its applicable laws.
      (2) the Government of the State of Kuwait and any legal person established or incorporated under the laws and regulations of the State of Kuwait, such as institutions, development funds, bodies, foundations, agencies, statutory establishments and other authorities, and companies.
   (b) With respect to the Republic of San Marino:
      (1) a natural person holding the nationality of a Contracting Party or permanently residing in the territory of a Contracting Party in accordance with its laws and who makes an investment in the territory of the other Contracting Party.
      (2) any legal person established, incorporated or organized in accordance with the laws and regulations of a Contracting Party, having a real business activity in the territory of that Contracting Party and investing in the territory of the other Contracting Party.
3. "Returns" means the amounts yielded by an investment, regardless of the form in which they are paid, and in particular, though not exclusively, includes profits, interests, capital gains, dividends, royalties, fees, administrative fees, technical assistance; and other payments and payments in kind.
4. The term "Territory" means:
   (a) With respect to the State of Kuwait: the territory of the State of Kuwait including any area outside the territorial sea which, in accordance with international law, has been or may hereafter be designated under the law of the State of Kuwait as an area over which the State of Kuwait may exercise sovereign rights or jurisdiction.

(b) For the Republic of San Marino: the territory of the Republic of San Marino.

5. "Without delay" means such period as is normally required for the completion of the necessary formalities for the transfer of payments, provided that such period shall not exceed one month in any case.

6. "Freely convertible currency" means any currency that the International Monetary Fund determines, from time to time, as a freely usable currency in accordance with the Articles of Agreement of the International Monetary Fund and any amendments thereto.

## Article 2
### Promotion, Admission and Protection of Investments

1. Each Contracting Party shall encourage and create more favorable conditions for investments made by investors of the other Contracting Party in its territory, and in accordance with the rights granted to it by virtue of its laws, shall admit such investments.

2. The Contracting Parties shall use their best efforts to promote investments through the exchange of information, including but not limited to:
(a) any existing dispute concerning the potential investor;
(b) the shareholders of the potential investor if established as a company;
(c) the type of business activity practiced by the potential investor;
(d) the geographical area and market sector in which it operates.
This information shall be provided to enable the host State to fulfill its obligations and perform its duties with respect to the investor or the investment under this Agreement and the national law of the host State.

3. Investments of investors of each Contracting Party shall at all times be accorded fair and equitable treatment and shall enjoy full protection and security in the territory of the other Contracting Party in a manner consistent with the recognized principles of its laws and regulations and the provisions of this Agreement.

4. Neither Contracting Party shall in any way impair, by unreasonable or discriminatory measures, the management, maintenance, use, enjoyment, expansion, sale, and, should it occur, liquidation of such investments in the territory of investors of the other Contracting Party.

5. Once investments are established, investments of investors of either Contracting Party shall not be subject to additional performance requirements which may be detrimental to their viability or adversely affect their use, management, conduct, operation, expansion, sale, or other disposition.

6. Each Contracting Party shall, in accordance with its laws and regulations relating to the entry, stay and work of natural persons, examine in good faith and give due consideration, regardless of nationality, to applications of key personnel including top managerial and technical persons who are employed for the purposes of investments in its territory to enter, stay temporarily and work in the territory of the host Contracting Party. The immediate family members of such key personnel shall be granted similar treatment with regard to the entry and temporary stay in the host Contracting Party.

## Article 3
### National Treatment

1. Each Contracting Party shall accord to investors of the other Contracting Party treatment no less favorable than that it accords, in like circumstances, to its own investors with respect to the establishment, acquisition, expansion, management, conduct, operation, sale or other disposition of investments in its territory, in accordance with its laws and regulations.

2. Each Contracting Party shall accord to covered investments treatment no less favorable than that it accords, in like circumstances, to investments in its territory of its own investors with respect to the establishment, acquisition, expansion, management, conduct, operation, sale or other disposition of investments.

3. For the avoidance of doubt, it is confirmed that the treatment provided for in paragraphs (1) and (2) above shall apply to the provisions of Articles 1 to 12 of this Agreement.

## Article 4
### Most-Favored-Nation Treatment

1. Each Contracting Party shall accord to investors of the other Contracting Party treatment no less favorable than that it accords, in like circumstances, to investors of any non-Party with respect to the establishment, acquisition, expansion, management, conduct, operation, sale or other disposition of investments in its territory.

2. Each Contracting Party shall accord to covered investments treatment no less favorable than that it accords, in like circumstances, to investments in its territory of investors of any non-Party with respect to the establishment, acquisition, expansion, management, conduct, operation, sale or other disposition of investments.

3. The provisions of this Article shall not, however, be construed so as to oblige one Contracting Party to extend to the investors of the other Contracting Party the benefit of any treatment, preference or privilege resulting from:
(a) any customs union, economic union, free trade area, monetary union, or any other form of regional economic arrangement or any similar international agreement, to which either of the Contracting Parties is or may become a party;
(b) any international or regional agreement or similar arrangement and any domestic legislation relating wholly or mainly to taxation.

## Article 5
### Compensation for Losses

1 - When investments made by investors of either Contracting Party suffer losses owing to war or other armed conflict, civil disturbances, a state of national emergency, revolution, riot, or similar events in the territory of the other Contracting Party, they shall be accorded by the latter Contracting Party treatment, as regards restitution, indemnification, compensation or other settlement, no less favorable than that which the latter Contracting Party accords to its own investors or to investors of any third State, whichever is more favorable to the investors.

2. Without prejudice to paragraph (1) of this Article, investors of one Contracting Party who in any of the events referred to in that paragraph suffer damage or loss in the territory of the other Contracting Party resulting from:
(a) the requisitioning of their investment or a part thereof by its forces or authorities;
(b) or the destruction of their investment or a part thereof by its forces or authorities, which was not caused in combat action or was not required by the necessity of the situation,
shall be accorded restitution or adequate and effective compensation for the damage or loss sustained during the period of the requisitioning or as a result of the destruction of their property. The resulting payments shall be in a freely convertible currency.

## Article 6
### Expropriation

Neither Contracting Party shall directly or indirectly expropriate or nationalize an investment in its territory of an investor of the other Contracting Party or take any measure or measures having an equivalent effect (hereinafter referred to as "expropriation") except:
(1) for a purpose which is in the public interest.
(2) on a non-discriminatory basis.
(3) in accordance with due process of law, and
(4) accompanied by the payment of prompt, adequate, and effective compensation.

b) Such compensation shall be equivalent to the market value of the expropriated investment immediately before the expropriation took place or before the impending expropriation became public knowledge, whichever is the earlier. It shall be determined and computed in accordance with internationally recognized principles of valuation and shall include interest at a normal commercial rate until the date of payment, shall be made without delay, be effectively realizable, and be in a freely convertible currency of the investor's choice. The investor affected shall have a right, under the law of the Contracting Party making the expropriation, to a prompt review, by a judicial or other independent authority of that Party, of his or its case and of the valuation of his or its investment in accordance with the principles set out in this paragraph.

2. For greater certainty, where a Contracting Party expropriates the assets of a company which is incorporated or constituted under the law in force in any part of its own territory, and in which investors of the other Contracting Party own shares, it shall ensure that the provisions of paragraph (1) of this Article are applied to the extent permitted to guarantee prompt, adequate and effective compensation in respect of their investment to such investors of the other Contracting Party who are owners of those shares.

3. For the purposes of this Agreement, the term "expropriation" shall also include any interventions or regulatory measures by a Contracting Party that have a de facto expropriatory effect, where their effect is to substantially deprive the investor of his ownership, control, or significant benefits over his investment or may result in loss or damage to the economic value of the investment.

4. Due process of law includes, in particular, the right of an investor of a Contracting Party who claims to be affected by expropriation by the other Contracting Party to a prompt review of his case, including the valuation of his investment and the payment of compensation in accordance with the provisions of this Article, by a judicial authority or other competent authority of the latter Contracting Party.

## Article 7
### Transfers

Each Contracting Party shall guarantee that all payments relating to an investment in its territory by an investor of the other Contracting Party may be freely transferred into and out of its territory without delay. Such transfers shall include, in particular, but not exclusively:
(a) the initial capital and additional amounts to maintain or increase the investment;
(b) profits, interest, capital gains, dividends, royalties, fees and other current income accruing from the investments;
(c) payments made under a contract including a loan in connection with the investments;
(d) the proceeds from the sale or liquidation of all or any part of the investments;
(e) payments of compensation under Articles 5, 6 and 8 of this Agreement;
(f) payments arising out of the settlement of an investment dispute under Articles 10 and 11 of this Agreement;
(g) earnings and remuneration of personnel engaged from abroad in connection with the investment.

1. Transfers of payments under paragraph (1) shall be effected without delay or restriction and in a freely convertible currency, except in the case of payments in kind. In case of a delay in effecting the required transfers, the affected investor shall be entitled to receive interest for the period of such delay.

2. Each Contracting Party shall guarantee that transfers under paragraph 1 of this Article shall be made in a freely convertible currency at the official rate of exchange prevailing

Each Contracting Party shall guarantee the calculation of interest at the LIBOR rate for the period commencing from the occurrence of the events under Articles 5 and 6(c) until the date of the transfer of payments, and the payment shall be executed in accordance with the provisions of paragraphs 1 and 2.

## Article 8
### Subrogation
1. If a Contracting Party or its designated agency (the indemnifying Contracting Party) makes a payment under an indemnity or guarantee it has assumed in respect of an investment in the territory of the other Contracting Party (the host Contracting Party), the host Contracting Party shall recognize:
   (a) the rights and claims of the indemnifying Contracting Party;
   (b) the rights of the indemnifying Contracting Party to enforce claims by virtue of subrogation to the same extent as the indemnified party was entitled, and it shall assume the obligations related to the investment.
2. The first Contracting Party shall, in all circumstances, be entitled to:
   (a) the same treatment in respect of the rights, claims, and obligations acquired by it, by virtue of the assignment;
   (b) any payments received by virtue of such rights and claims, as the indemnified party was entitled to receive under this Agreement, in respect of the investment concerned and its related returns.

## Article 9
### Settlement of Disputes between a Contracting Party and an Investor of the Other Contracting Party
Disputes arising between a Contracting Party and an investor of the other Contracting Party concerning an investment of the latter in the territory of the former shall, as far as possible, be settled amicably through negotiations.
1. If such a dispute is not settled within six (6) months from the date of a request for consultations by either contracting party, and if the two contracting parties do not agree otherwise in writing, either of the contracting parties may, by written notice to the other contracting party, refer the dispute to a special arbitration tribunal in accordance with the following provisions of this Article. The investor party to the dispute may choose to settle the dispute through one of the following means:
   (a) in accordance with any pre-agreed dispute settlement procedures;
   (b) by a competent court of the Contracting Party in which the investment was made;
   (c) to international arbitration in accordance with the following paragraphs of this Article.
2. In the event the investor chooses to refer the dispute to international arbitration, the investor must submit their written consent to refer the dispute to one of the following bodies:
   (a) The International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes ("the Centre"), established by the Convention on the Settlement of Investment Disputes between States and Nationals of Other States, opened for signature in Washington, D.C., on March 18, 1965 ("the Washington Convention"), if both Contracting Parties are parties to the Washington Convention and the Washington Convention is applicable to the dispute;
   (2) The Centre, under the Rules Governing the Additional Facility for the Administration of Proceedings by the Secretariat of the Centre ("the Additional Facility Rules"), if the Contracting Party of the investor or the Contracting Party to the dispute, but not both, is a party to the Washington Convention;
   (b) Ad hoc arbitration in accordance with the Arbitration Rules ("the Rules") of the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL), as may be modified by the parties to the dispute (the appointing authority referred to in Article 7 of the Rules shall be the Secretary-General of the Centre);
   (c) or an arbitration tribunal established in accordance with the arbitration rules of any arbitration institution agreed upon by the parties to the dispute.
3. Notwithstanding that the investor has submitted a dispute to binding arbitration under paragraph 3, they may, before the commencement of or during the arbitral proceedings, request the judicial or administrative courts of the Contracting Party that is a party to the dispute to issue an interim injunction to protect their rights and interests, provided that the request does not include a claim for payment of any damages.
4. In any judicial, arbitral, or other proceedings, or in the enforcement of any decision or award, relating to an investment dispute between a Contracting Party and an investor of the other Contracting Party, the Contracting Party may not raise its sovereign immunity as a defense. Any counterclaim or right to set-off may not be based on the fact that the investor concerned has received or will receive, under an insurance contract, compensation or other indemnity for all or part of their alleged damages from any third party whatsoever, whether public or private, including the other Contracting Party and its subdivisions, agencies, or instrumentalities.

## Article 10
### Settlement of Disputes between the Contracting Parties
1. Disputes between the Contracting Parties concerning the interpretation or application of this Agreement shall be resolved through diplomatic channels and settled as far as possible by negotiation.
2. If the dispute is not settled within six (6) months from the date of a request for consultations by either of the Contracting Parties, unless the Contracting Parties agree otherwise in writing, either Contracting Party may, by written notice to the other Contracting Party, submit the dispute to an ad hoc arbitration tribunal in accordance with the following provisions of this Article.
3. The arbitration tribunal shall be constituted as follows: each Contracting Party shall appoint one member, and these two members shall agree to appoint a national of

These members shall be appointed within two (2) months, and the Chairman shall be appointed within four (4) months from the date on which either Contracting Party has notified the other Contracting Party of its intention to submit the dispute to an arbitral tribunal.
4. If the time periods specified in paragraph 3 above have not been complied with, either Contracting Party may, in the absence of any other arrangement, invite the President of the International Court of Justice to make the necessary appointments. If the President of the International Court of Justice is a national of either Contracting Party or is otherwise unable to discharge the said function, the Vice-President of the International Court of Justice shall be invited to make the necessary appointments. If the Vice-President of the International Court of Justice is a national of either Contracting Party or is also unable to discharge the said function, the Member of the International Court of Justice next in seniority who is not a national of either Contracting Party shall be invited to make the necessary appointments.
5. The arbitral tribunal shall issue its decision by a majority of votes. Such decision shall be made in accordance with this Agreement and the recognized rules of international law as may be applicable, and shall be final and binding on both Contracting Parties. Each Contracting Party shall bear the costs of the member appointed by it to the arbitral tribunal, as well as the costs of its representation in the arbitration proceedings. The expenses of the Chairman and any other costs of the arbitration proceedings shall be shared equally between the Contracting Parties. However, the arbitral tribunal may, at its discretion, direct that a higher proportion or all of such costs be paid by one of the Contracting Parties. In all other respects, the arbitral tribunal shall determine its own procedures.

## Article 11
Application of Other Provisions
1. If the provisions of the law of either Contracting Party or obligations under international law, existing at present or established hereafter between the Contracting Parties in addition to this Agreement, contain provisions, whether general or specific, granting investments by investors of the other Contracting Party a treatment more favorable than that provided for in this Agreement, such provisions shall prevail over this Agreement to the extent that they provide more favorable treatment.
2. More favorable terms than those of this Agreement which have been agreed to by one of the Contracting Parties with investors of the other Contracting Party shall not be affected by this Agreement.
3. Nothing in this Agreement shall affect the provisions contained in international agreements concerning intellectual and industrial property rights in force at the date of its signature.

## Article 12
Scope of the Agreement
This Agreement shall apply to all investments, whether made before or after the date of entry into force of this Agreement, but shall not apply to any dispute concerning an investment which arose before its entry into force or any claim concerning an investment which was settled before its entry into force.

## Article 13
Relations between the Contracting Parties
The provisions of this Agreement shall apply irrespective of the existence of diplomatic or consular relations between the Contracting Parties.

## Article 14
Entry into Force
Each of the Contracting Parties shall notify the other in writing of the completion of the constitutional requirements in its territory for the entry into force of this Agreement. This Agreement shall enter into force on the thirtieth (30th) day after the date of receipt of the last of the two notifications.

## Article 15
Duration and Termination
1. This Agreement shall remain in force for a period of fifteen (15) years and shall continue in force thereafter for a similar period or periods unless, at least one year before the expiry of the initial or any subsequent period, either Contracting Party notifies the other Contracting Party in writing of its intention to terminate this Agreement.
2. In respect of investments made prior to the date of the notice of termination of this Agreement becoming effective, the provisions of this Agreement shall remain in force for a period of fifteen (15) years from the date of termination of this Agreement.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the undersigned, duly authorized thereto by their respective Governments, have signed this Agreement.
Done in New York City, in two originals, on this 24th day of Rabi' al-Awwal 1446 H, corresponding to the 27th day of September 2024, in the Arabic, Italian, and English languages, all texts being equally authentic. In case of divergence, the English text shall prevail.

# AGREEMENT

**BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF KUWAIT**

**AND**

**THE GOVERNMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF SAN MARINO**

**FOR THE PROMOTION AND RECIPROCAL PROTECTION**

**OF INVESTMENTS**

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of San Marino, (hereinafter referred to as the “Contracting Parties”);

Desiring to promote greater economic cooperation between them, with respect to investment by nationals and legal entities of one Contracting Party in the territory of the other Contracting Party, as well as a healthy, stable and sustainable development of the economy;

Recognizing that agreement upon the treatment to be accorded to such investment will stimulate the flow of private capital and the economic development of the Contracting Parties;

Agreeing that a stable framework for investment will maximize effective utilization of economic resources and improve living standards;

Having resolved to conclude the Agreement on the promotion and reciprocal protection of investments,

Have agreed as follows:

  The term "investment" means every kind of right or asset invested by an investor of a Contracting Party in the territory of the other Contracting Party, owned or controlled directly or indirectly, and shall include though in particular, though not exclusively:
    (a) shares, stocks, and other forms of equity participation, and bonds, debentures, other forms of participation in companies or debt interests in a company, and other debts and loans and securities issued by any investor of a Contracting Party;
    (b) claims to money or to any contractual performance having an economic value;
    (c) intellectual property rights, including, but not limited to, copyrights, trademarks, patents, industrial designs and patterns and technical processes, know-how, trade secrets, trade names and goodwill;
    (d) any right conferred by law, contract or by virtue of any licenses or permits granted pursuant to law, including rights to prospect, explore, extract, or utilize natural resources;
    (e) any tangible or intangible, movable and immovable property and any related property rights, such as leases, mortgages, liens and pledges, usufructs and similar rights;
    (f) "returns" retained for the purpose of re-investment and to proceeds from "liquidation".

    Any change in the form in which assets or rights are invested or reinvested shall not affect their character as investments.

2.  The term "investor" means:
    (a) with respect to the State of Kuwait:
    1) a natural person who is a National of the State of Kuwait in accordance with its applicable laws;
    2) the Government of the State of Kuwait and any juridical person constituted or incorporated under the laws and regulation of the State of Kuwait, such as institutions, development funds.

6. "Freely convertible currency" means any currency that the International Monetary Fund determines, from time to time, as freely usable currency in accordance with the Articles of Agreement of the International Monetary Fund and any amendment thereto.

## Article 3
### National Treatment

1. Each Contracting Party shall accord to investors of the other Contracting Party treatment no less favourable than that it accords, in like circumstances, to its own investors with respect to the establishment, acquisition, expansion, management, conduct, operation, and sale or other disposition of investments in its territory, according to its laws and regulations.

2. Each Contracting Party shall accord to covered investments treatment no less favourable than that it accords, in like circumstances, to investments in its territory of its own investors with respect to establishment, acquisition, expansion, management, conduct, operation, and sale or other disposition of investments, according to its laws and regulations.

3. For the avoidance of doubt it is confirmed that the treatment provided for in paragraphs (1) and (2) above shall apply to the provisions of Articles 1 to 12 of this Agreement.

## Article 4
### Most-Favoured-Nation Treatment

1. Each Contracting Party shall accord to investors of the other Party treatment no less favourable than that it accords, in like circumstances, to investors of any non-Party with respect to the establishment, acquisition, expansion, management, conduct, operation, and sale or other disposition of investments in its territory.

### Article 5
**Compensation for Losses**

1. 2. Without prejudice to paragraph 1 of this Article, investors of one Contracting Party who in any of the events referred to in that paragraph suffers damage or loss in the territory of the other Contracting Party resulting from:
   (a) requisitioning of its investments or part thereof by its forces or authorities;

## Article 6
## Expropriation

1.  a) A Contracting Party shall not expropriate or nationalize directly or indirectly an investment in its territory of an investor of another Contracting Party or take any measure or measures having equivalent effect (hereinafter referred to as "expropriation") except:
    (1) for a purpose which is in the public interest;
    (2) on a non-discriminatory basis;
    (3) in accordance with due process of law; and
    (4) accompanied by payment of prompt adequate and effective compensation.

    b) Such compensation shall amount to the market value of the investment expropriated immediately before the expropriation or before the impending expropriation became public knowledge, whichever is earlier. It shall be determined and calculated in accordance with internationally recognized principles of valuation and shall include interest at a normal commercial rate until the date of payment, shall be made without delay, be freely convertible currency to be chosen by the investor. The investor affected shall have a right, under the law of the Contracting Party making the expropriation, to prompt review, by a judicial or other independent authority of that Party, of his or its case and of the valuation of his or its investment in accordance with the principles set out in this paragraph.

2.  For greater certainty, expropriation shall include situations where a Contracting Party expropriates the assets of a company or enterprise which is incorporated or constituted under the law in force in any

For the purposes of this Agreement, the term "expropriation" shall also include any interventions or regulatory measures by a Contracting Party that have a de facto expropriatory effect, in that their effect results in depriving the investor in fact from his ownership, control or substantial benefits over his investment or which may result in loss or damage to the economic value of the investment.

4. Due process of law includes, in particular, the right of an investor of a Contracting Party which claims to be affected by expropriation by another Contracting Party to prompt review of its case, including the valuation of its investment and the payment of compensation in accordance with the provisions of this Article, by a judicial authority or another competent authority of the latter Contracting Party.

## Article 7
## Transfers

1. Each Contracting Party shall ensure that all payments relating to an investment in its territory of an investor of another Contracting Party may be freely transferred into and out of its territory without delay. Such transfers shall include, in particular, though not exclusively:
    (a) the initial capital and additional amounts to maintain or increase an investment;
    (b) profits, interests, capital gains, dividends, royalties, fees and other current income accruing from investments;
    (c) payments made under a contract including a loan connected with the investments;
    (d) proceeds from the sale or liquidation of all or any part of the investments;

## Article 9
**Settlement of Disputes between a Contracting Party, and an Investor of the other Contracting Party**

1. Disputes arising between a Contracting Party and an investor of the other Contracting Party in respect of an investment of the latter in the territory of the former shall, as far as possible, be settled amicably by negotiations.

2. If such a dispute has not been settled within six (6) months following the date on which consultations were requested by either Contracting Party and unless the Contracting Parties otherwise agreed in writing, either Contracting Party may by written notice to the other Contracting Party, submit the dispute to an ad hoc arbitral tribunal in accordance with the following provisions of this Article. The dispute shall be submitted for resolution, at the election of the investor party to the dispute, through one of the following means:
    (a) in accordance with any applicable, previously agreed dispute settlement procedures;
    (b) by a competent court of the Contracting Party, in whose territory the investment has been made; or
    (c) to international arbitration in accordance with the following paragraphs of this Article.

3. In the event that an investor elects to submit the dispute for resolution to international arbitration, the investor shall further provide its consent in writing for the dispute to be submitted to one of the following bodies:
    (a) (1) The International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes ("The Centre"), established by the Convention on the

(2) The Centre, under the rules governing the Additional Facility for the Administration of Proceedings by the Secretariat of the Centre (the "Additional Facility Rules"), if the Contracting Party of the investor or the Contracting Party to the dispute, but not both, is a party to the Washington Convention;

(c) or an arbitral tribunal constituted pursuant to the arbitration rules of any arbitral institution mutually agreed upon between the parties to the dispute.

4. Notwithstanding the fact that the investor may have submitted a dispute to binding arbitration under paragraph 3, it may, prior to the institution of the arbitral proceeding or during the proceeding, seek before the judicial or administrative tribunals of the Contracting Party that is a party to the dispute, interim injunctive relief for the preservation of its rights and interests, provided it does not include a request for payment of any damages.

5. In any proceedings, judicial, arbitral or otherwise or in an enforcement of any decision or award, concerning an investment dispute between a Contracting Party and an investor of the other Contracting Party, a Contracting Party shall not assert, as a defense, its sovereign immunity. Any counterclaim or right of set-off may not be based on the fact that the investor concerned has received or will receive, pursuant to an insurance contract, indemnification or other compensation for all or part of its alleged damages from any third party whomsoever, whether public or private, including such other Contracting Party and its subdivisions, agencies or instrumentalities.

2. If a dispute has not been settled within six (6) months following the date on which consultations were requested by either Contracting Party and unless the Contracting Parties otherwise agree in writing, either Contracting Party may, by written notice to the other Contracting Party, submit the dispute to an ad hoc arbitral tribunal in accordance with the following provisions of this Article.

3. The arbitral tribunal shall be constituted as follows: each Contracting Party shall appoint one member, and these two members shall agree upon a national of a third party as Chairman of the arbitral tribunal to be appointed by the two Contracting Parties. Such members shall be appointed within two (2) months, and such Chairman within four (4) months, from the date on which either Contracting Party has informed the other Contracting Party that it intends to submit the dispute to an arbitral tribunal.

4. If the periods specified in paragraph 3 above have not been complied with, either Contracting Party may, in the absence of any other arrangement, invite the President of the International Court of Justice to make the necessary appointments. If the President of the International Court of Justice is a national of either Contracting Party or if he is otherwise prevented from discharging the said function, the Vice-President of the International Court of Justice shall be invited to make the necessary appointments. If the Vice-President of the International Court of Justice is a national of either Contracting Party or if he too is prevented from discharging the said function, the Member of the International Court of Justice next in seniority who is not a national of either Contracting Party shall be invited to make the necessary appointments.

5. The arbitral tribunal shall take its decision by a majority of votes. Such decision shall be made in accordance with this Agreement and recognised rules of international law as it may be applicable and shall be final and binding on both Contracting Parties. Each

 The expenses of the Chairman as well as any other costs of the arbitration proceedings shall be borne in equal parts by the two Contracting Parties. However, the arbitral tribunal may, at its discretion, direct that a higher proportion or all of such costs be paid by one of the Contracting Parties. In all other respects, the arbitral tribunal shall determine its own procedure.

### Article 11
***Application of Other Rules***

1. If the legislation of either Contracting Party or obligations under international law existing at present or established hereafter between the Contracting Parties in addition to this Agreement, contain rules, whether general or specific, entitling investments by investors of the other Contracting Party to a treatment more favorable than is provided for by this Agreement, such rules shall to the extent that they are more favorable to the investor prevail over this Agreement.

2. More favourable terms than those of this Agreement which one of the Contracting Parties has agreed to investors of the other Contracting Party shall not be affected by this Agreement.

3. Nothing in this Agreement shall affect the provisions set out in the international agreements relating to intellectual and industrial property rights in force on the date of its signature.

### Article 12
***Scope of the Agreement***

This Agreement shall apply to all investments, whether made before or after its entry into force, but shall not apply to any dispute concerning an investment which arose, or any claim concerning an investment which was settled, before its entry into force.

### Article 14
***Entry into Force***

Each Contracting Party shall notify the other in writing when its constitutional requirements for the entry into force of this Agreement have been fulfilled. This Agreement shall enter into force on the thirtieth (30th) day after the date of receipt of the latter of the two notifications.

### Article 15
***Duration and Termination***

1. This Agreement shall remain in force for a period of fifteen (15) years and shall continue in force thereafter for similar period or periods unless, at least one year before the expiry of the initial or any subsequent period, either Contracting Party notifies the other Contracting Party in writing of its intention to terminate this Agreement.

2. In respect of investments made prior to the date when the notice of termination of this Agreement becomes effective, the provisions of this Agreement shall continue to be effective for a period of fifteen (15) years from the date of termination of this Agreement.

# Decree No. 126 of 2025
## Appointing a Non-Resident Ambassador

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhul-Qi'dah 1445 H, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Law No. 21 of 1962 regarding the Diplomatic and Consular Corps, and its amending laws,
- And upon the proposal of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And with the approval of the Council of Ministers,

**We have decreed the following**

### Article One
Mr. Mohammed Yaqoub Hayati <orig>محمد يعقوب حياتي</orig> - Ambassador of the State of Kuwait to the Kingdom of Sweden - is appointed, in addition to his current duties, as a Non-Resident Ambassador of the State of Kuwait to the Republic of Finland.

### Article Two
The Minister of Foreign Affairs shall implement this decree, and it shall come into force from the date of its issuance and be published in the Official Gazette.

# Decree No. 128 of 2025
## Approving the Memorandum of Understanding for Technical Cooperation in the Field of Accreditation and Conformity Assessment between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Tunisia

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 H, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And based on the proposal of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And with the approval of the Council of Ministers,

**We have decreed the following**

### Article One
The Memorandum of Understanding for Technical Cooperation in the Field of Accreditation and Conformity Assessment between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Republic of Tunisia <orig>الجمهورية التونسية</orig>, signed in the city of Tunis on 20 November 2024, the text of which is attached to this decree, is hereby approved.

### Article Two
The Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this decree, and it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette.

Emir of Kuwait
Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>

Prime Minister

Minister of Foreign Affairs
Abdullah Ali Abdullah Al-Yahya <orig>عبد الله علي عبد الله اليحيا</orig>

## Memorandum of Understanding for Technical Cooperation in the Field of Accreditation and Conformity Assessment between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Tunisia

The Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, represented by the (Public Authority for Industry <orig>الهيئة العامة للصناعة</orig>), and the Government of the Republic of Tunisia <orig>الجمهورية التونسية</orig>, represented by the (National Accreditation Council <orig>المجلس الوطني للاعتماد</orig>), hereinafter referred to as "the Parties."
Proceeding from the bonds of Islamic and Arab brotherhood and the bilateral relations that connect the two brotherly countries.
And based on the desire of both Parties to enhance, strengthen, and establish cooperation between them and to provide a scientific basis for regulating accreditation and conformity assessment systems.

Have agreed as follows:

## Article One
### (Scope of the Memorandum)
The scope of this Memorandum of Understanding is to strengthen mutual cooperation between the two Parties by activating technical exchange relations and sharing expertise in the field of accreditation and conformity assessment, and by facilitating trade exchange between the Republic of Tunisia and the State of Kuwait.

## Article Two
### (Areas of Cooperation)
The National Accreditation Council <orig>المجلس الوطني للاعتماد</orig> of the Republic of Tunisia shall provide technical support for the development of the accreditation system for the Accreditation Affairs Department at the Public Authority for Industry <orig>الهيئة العامة للصناعة</orig> in the State of Kuwait, in line with relevant international requirements in the field of accreditation, according to an agreed-upon work program.

## Article Three
### (Peer Evaluation)
The National Accreditation Council <orig>المجلس الوطني للاعتماد</orig> of the Republic of Tunisia shall provide technical support to the Accreditation Affairs Department at the Public Authority for Industry <orig>الهيئة العامة للصناعة</orig> in the State of Kuwait in implementing peer evaluation procedures for regional and international accreditation bodies, with the aim of achieving the signing of multilateral agreements and mutual recognition arrangements.

## Article Four
### (Qualification of Assessors)
The National Accreditation Council <orig>المجلس الوطني للاعتماد</orig> of the Republic of Tunisia shall qualify a number of assessors from the Accreditation Affairs Department of the Public Authority for Industry <orig>الهيئة العامة للصناعة</orig> in the State of Kuwait, in accordance with the procedures and requirements of regional and international accreditation bodies related to the qualification of assessors in the fields of accreditation and conformity assessment.

## Article Five
### (Training)
The two Parties shall organize training courses on accreditation and conformity assessment. Each Party shall provide the other with its approved annual training plan and shall work to provide the other Party with the opportunity to participate, whether in training operations or in organizing joint training courses, according to the available capabilities of both Parties.

## Article Six
### (Exchange of Expertise)
The two Parties shall exchange the expertise available to each in the field of accreditation and conformity assessment and shall utilize the technical experts and assessors of both Parties to conduct joint assessments, according to the available capabilities and in accordance with procedures agreed upon between the two Parties.

## Article Seven
### (Exchange and Coordination of Information and Events)
The two Parties shall exchange information, documents, and publications, and coordinate activities and events related to accreditation between them at the regional and international levels. This includes organizing awareness seminars on accreditation and conformity assessment, as well as exchanging invitations to attend and participate in events held by either Party.

## Article Eight
### (Cooperation and Partnership)
Several cooperation and partnership agreements may arise from this Memorandum of Understanding, by agreement between the two Parties, in areas concerning the Accreditation Affairs Department of the Public Authority for Industry <orig>الهيئة العامة للصناعة</orig> in the State of Kuwait and the National Accreditation Council <orig>المجلس الوطني للاعتماد</orig> of the Republic of Tunisia.

## Article Nine
### (Applicable Law)
The provisions of this Memorandum shall not prejudice the laws in force in either country or the rights or obligations of either state arising from international treaties and agreements to which either is a party.

## Article Ten
### (Settlement of Disputes)
Any dispute that may arise concerning the interpretation or implementation of this Memorandum of Understanding shall be settled between the two Parties through diplomatic channels, and through consultations and negotiations.

## Article Eleven
### (Final Provisions)
1. This Memorandum of Understanding shall enter into force on the date of receipt of the last notification by which one Party informs the other, in writing and through diplomatic channels, of the completion of its necessary national procedures for its entry into force.
2. This Memorandum of Understanding shall remain in effect for a period of five years from the date of its entry into force and shall be automatically renewed for a similar period or periods, unless one of the Parties notifies the other in writing, through diplomatic channels, of its desire to terminate this Memorandum at least six (6) months prior to its expiration date.
3. This Memorandum of Understanding may be amended in writing by agreement of the two Parties at any time. Such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures set forth in the first paragraph of this Article.
4. The termination of this Memorandum shall not affect the validity or duration of any specific agreements, projects, and activities undertaken on the occasion of this Memorandum, unless the two Parties agree otherwise.

Done in the city of Tunis on Wednesday, 20 November 2024, in two original copies in the Arabic language, both having equal legal validity.

## Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Arab Republic of Egypt in the Field of Enhancing Competition Protection

### Preamble
The Government of the State of Kuwait, represented by the Kuwaiti Competition Protection Agency, and the Government of the Arab Republic of Egypt, represented by the Competition Protection Agency, hereinafter referred to as the "Parties," being keen to strengthen the existing friendly and economic relations between them and desiring to expand and deepen mutual knowledge, understanding, and effective enforcement of competition rules, through the exchange of information, expertise, and cooperation in the field of competition protection,
Have agreed as follows:

## Article (1)
### Purpose
The Parties shall seek to develop and enhance cooperation between them by establishing a framework for cooperation in the field of competition protection and the prevention of harmful monopolistic practices that restrict, limit, or prevent free competition.

## Article (2)
### Areas of Cooperation
Cooperation between the Parties shall include the following areas:
1. Exchanging information and expertise in the field of competition protection and the prevention of monopolistic practices, in a manner that facilitates and enhances the performance of the Parties' functions, especially concerning the role of competition advocacy in competition protection agencies and how to develop policies that would promote competition in the markets of both countries.
2. Organizing conferences, visits, and training courses in the field of competition protection, laws, and competition policies.
3. Exchanging experts to participate in professional activities and assist in the application of laws and policies in order to develop decision-making processes.
4. Exchanging consultations through visits to the headquarters of the competition protection agencies in both countries, or via email, or through other means of communication between the experts, technicians, and specialists of the Parties, to ensure the flow of information exchange on topics of mutual interest.
5. Exchanging information regarding the establishment of an integrated database.
6. Exchanging information regarding the mechanism for examining complaints, requests, and notifications.
7. Exchanging studies, research, and publications necessary for analyzing different market practices to detect cases harmful to competition and monopolistic practices.
8. Exchanging periodic bulletins, procedures, and measures in the field of competition protection.
9. Exchanging information and expertise on cases, legislative rules, and other legal instruments based on the activities carried out by the Parties to achieve the desired efficiency in the field of competition.
10. Exchanging information on the results of research conducted by the Parties and their practical applications in the field of combating monopolistic and anti-competitive practices and promoting competition.
11. Exchanging information on market developments and the decisions taken in that regard.
12. Exchanging expertise related to investigation and inquiry procedures concerning violations of competition laws.
13. Developing mutual support and exchanging views on preparing for international activities, such as organizing conferences and participating in international conferences on competition.
14. Examining and studying cases of mutual interest as required by each case, and in accordance with local laws.
15. Developing mutual support and exchanging views on preparing for international activities.
16. Any other areas to be agreed upon later between the parties to the agreement.

## Article (3)
### Exchange and Confidentiality of Information
1. The Parties shall be committed to applying the provisions of the laws and regulations governing the confidentiality of information in their respective countries.

# Decree No. 130 of 2025 Approving the Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Sultanate of Oman in the Field of Competition Protection

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 H, corresponding to May 10, 2024 AD,
- And based on the proposal of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And with the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,

**We have decreed the following**

## Article One
The Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Sultanate of Oman <orig>سلطنة عمان</orig> in the field of competition protection, signed in Kuwait City <orig>مدينة الكويت</orig> on 16/11/2023, the text of which is attached to this decree, is hereby approved.

## Article Two
The ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this decree, and it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

**Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>**

# Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait, represented by the Competition Protection Agency, and the Government of the Sultanate of Oman, represented by the Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Investment Promotion, in the Field of Enhancing Competition Protection

The Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, represented by the Competition Protection Agency <orig>جهاز حماية المنافسة</orig>, and the Government of the Sultanate of Oman <orig>سلطنة عمان</orig>, represented by the Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Investment Promotion <orig>وزارة التجارة والصناعة وترويج الاستثمار</orig>, hereinafter referred to as "the two Parties," keen to strengthen the existing friendly relations between them, and desiring to expand and deepen mutual knowledge and understanding through the exchange of information, expertise, and cooperation in the field of competition protection, and in light of the discussions held between the two Parties.

The two Parties have agreed as follows:

2. The two Parties shall commit to not disclosing confidential information exchanged between them, and it may not be disclosed except with the written consent of the concerned Party or in accordance with the mechanism agreed upon.

## Article (4)
### Correspondence and Points of Contact
1. The exchange of information related to the implementation of this Memorandum of Understanding shall be conducted through written correspondence in the Arabic language, via email, fax, or during meetings attended by representatives of the two Parties.
2. Each Party shall designate units responsible for coordination within the framework of implementing this Memorandum.
3. The two Parties shall commit to notifying each other of any change in the contact details of the units responsible for coordination activities related to this Memorandum.

## Article (5)
### Dispute Settlement
Any dispute regarding the interpretation or implementation of this Memorandum of Understanding shall be resolved amicably through consultation and negotiation via the existing diplomatic channels between the two countries, without resorting to any national or international court or any third party for settlement.

## Article (6)
All activities contained in this Memorandum must comply with the laws in force in both countries.

## Article (7)
1. This Memorandum of Understanding shall enter into force from the date of receipt by the Government of the Arab Republic of Egypt of a written notification from the Government of the State of Kuwait, through diplomatic channels, of its completion of all necessary national legal procedures for its entry into force.
2. This Memorandum of Understanding may be amended with the consent of both Parties, and such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures stipulated in paragraph (1) of this Article.
3. This Memorandum shall remain in effect for a period of five years, renewable for similar periods, unless either Party notifies the other in writing through diplomatic channels of its desire to terminate it, at least six months prior to its expiration date.
4. The termination of this Memorandum shall not affect ongoing activities or executive programs being carried out under this Memorandum.

This Memorandum was drawn up and signed in the city of Cairo <orig>مدينة القاهرة</orig> on Thursday, September 12, 2024, in two original copies in the Arabic language, both having the same legal validity.

# Article (1)
The two Parties seek to establish a framework between them in the field of cooperation in protecting competition and preventing harmful monopolistic practices that restrict, limit, or prevent free competition, and to develop and enhance cooperation between the two Parties.

# Article (2)
The two Parties shall encourage cooperation in the following areas:
a. Exchanging information and expertise in the field of competition protection and prevention of monopolistic practices, in a manner that facilitates and enhances the performance of the two Parties' functions, especially concerning the role of competitive guidance in competition protection agencies, and how to develop policies that would enhance competition in the markets of both countries.
b. Organizing conferences, visits, and training courses in the field of competition protection, laws, and competition policies.
c. Exchanging experts to participate in professional activities, and assisting in the application of laws and policies to develop decision-making processes.
d. Exchanging consultations through visits to the headquarters of the competition protection agencies in both countries, or through email and other means of communication between the experts, technicians, and specialists of the two Parties, to ensure the smooth exchange of information on topics of common interest.
e. Exchanging information regarding the establishment of an integrated database.
f. Exchanging information regarding the mechanism for examining complaints, requests, and notifications.
g. Exchanging studies, research, and publications necessary for analyzing different market practices to detect cases harmful to competition and monopolistic practices.
h. Exchanging periodic bulletins, procedures, and measures in the field of competition protection.
i. Exchanging information and expertise on cases, legislative rules, and other legal instruments based on the activities carried out by the two Parties to achieve the desired efficiency in the field of competition.
j. Exchanging information on the results of research conducted by the two Parties and their practical applications in the field of combating monopolistic and anti-competitive practices, and promoting them.
k. Exchanging information on market developments and the decisions taken in this regard.
l. Exchanging expertise related to investigation and inquiry procedures concerning violations of competition laws.
m. Developing mutual support and exchanging views on preparing for international activities such as organizing conferences and participating in international conferences specialized in competition.
n. Examining and studying cases of common interest as required by each case, and in accordance with local laws.
o. Developing mutual support and exchanging views on preparing for international activities.
p. Exchanging studies related to electronic competition and the prevention of electronic monopolies.
The two Parties may add other areas of cooperation through diplomatic channels.

# Article (3)
1. The two Parties shall be committed to applying the provisions of the laws and regulations governing the confidentiality of information in their respective countries.
2. The two Parties shall be committed not to disclose confidential information exchanged between them, and it may not be disclosed except with the written consent of the concerned Party, or according to the mechanism agreed upon.

# Article (4)
1. Each Party shall designate units responsible for coordination within the framework of implementing this Memorandum.
2. The exchange of information related to the application of this Memorandum shall be conducted through written correspondence in the Arabic language, via email, fax, or by the coordination units designated by the two Parties, or during meetings attended by representatives of the two Parties.
3. The two Parties shall be committed to notifying each other as soon as possible of any changes in the contact details of the units responsible for coordination activities related to this Memorandum.

# Article (5)
Executive programs concerning the implementation of this Memorandum may be concluded if the need arises.

# Article (6)
The two Parties shall settle any disputes arising from the application or interpretation of the provisions of this Memorandum amicably through consultations via diplomatic channels.

# Article (7)
The two Parties shall act upon this Memorandum in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in both countries.

# Article (8)
1. This Memorandum shall enter into force on the date of the last notification by which one Party informs the other, through diplomatic channels, of the completion of all internal procedures necessary for its implementation.
2. The Memorandum of Understanding may be amended with the consent of both Parties, and these amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures stipulated in paragraph (1) of this Article.
3. This Memorandum shall remain in effect for a period of (5) five years, automatically renewed for a similar period, unless either Party notifies the other in writing, through diplomatic channels, of its desire to terminate it, at least (6) six months prior to its expiration date. The termination of this Memorandum shall not affect the ongoing activities or executive programs being carried out under this Memorandum.

This Memorandum was signed in Kuwait City on Thursday, 2 Jumada al-Awwal 1445 H, corresponding to 16 November 2023 G, in two original copies in the Arabic language, both having the same legal validity.

## Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan in the Field of Industrial Cooperation

The Government of the State of Kuwait, represented by the Public Authority for Industry <orig>الهيئة العامة للصناعة</orig>, and the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan, represented by the Ministry of Industry and New Technologies <orig>وزارة الصناعة والتكنولوجيا الحديثة</orig>, hereinafter referred to as the "Contracting Parties",
In pursuit of the goal of supporting cooperation between the Contracting Parties for industrial development in both countries,
Have agreed as follows:

### Article 1: General Areas of Cooperation
1. To increase cooperation in the field of management techniques, technological development, and activities supporting industrial research and development between the two countries.
2. To organize the exchange of marketing research to identify industrial needs and to exchange expertise in development.

### Article 2: Basic Principles of Cooperation and Production
1. To develop joint research and projects based on the principles of cooperation and mutual benefit, and in accordance with the legislation in both countries.
2. To increase cooperation in the aforementioned fields, including the exchange of advanced technology.

### Article 3: Organization of Cooperation
1. To exchange lists of responsible persons and their contact information to ensure effective interaction.
2. To develop a detailed program that includes directions of cooperation of mutual interest.
3. To conclude the necessary agreements and contracts for the successful implementation of specific activities.

### Article 4: Confidentiality
1. To commit to using the information provided exclusively within the framework of this Memorandum, ensuring its confidentiality and protection from unauthorized access by third parties.
2. To strictly adhere to the confidentiality regime during joint research and activities.

### Article 5: Financial Responsibility
The Contracting Party requesting the services shall bear any financial expenses arising from the support provided under this Memorandum of Understanding, unless otherwise agreed.

### Article 6: Settlement of Disputes
Any dispute that may arise concerning the interpretation and/or implementation of this Memorandum of Understanding shall be settled between the Contracting Parties through diplomatic channels, and through consultations and negotiations.

### Article 7: Entry into Force
1. This Memorandum of Understanding shall enter into force on the date of receipt of the last notification by which one Contracting Party informs the other Contracting Party, in writing and through diplomatic channels, of the completion of its necessary national procedures for its entry into force.
2. This Memorandum of Understanding may be amended in writing by agreement of the Contracting Parties at any time. Such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures set forth in the first paragraph of this Article.
3. This Memorandum of Understanding shall remain in effect for a period of (3) years from the date of its entry into force, and shall be automatically renewed for a similar period or periods, unless one of the Contracting Parties notifies the other Party in writing and through diplomatic channels of its desire to terminate this Memorandum (6) months prior to its expiration date.
4. The termination of this Memorandum of Understanding shall not affect the validity or duration of any specific agreements, projects, and activities undertaken on the occasion of this Memorandum of Understanding.

Done in Kuwait City on November 3, 2024, in two original copies in the Arabic, Tajik, and English languages, all texts being equally authentic. In case of divergence in interpretation, the English text shall prevail.

**For**

 General Directions of Cooperation:
1. Strengthening interaction in the field of management techniques, research and development, contributing to the development of the industries in both countries.
2. Organization of exchange in marketing research to identify the needs in industrial products and share experiences in developing effective production methods.

## ARTICLE 2. Basic Principles of Cooperation:
1. Development of joint research and projects based on the principles of good faith cooperation, mutual benefit, and equality, with respect for the legislation of both countries.
2. Active interaction in the mentioned areas, including the exchange of advanced technologies and practices.

## ARTICLE 3. Cooperation Organization:
1. Exchange of lists of responsible persons and their contact information to ensure effective interaction.
2. Development of a detailed program, including directions of cooperation that represent mutual interest.
3. Conclusion of necessary agreements and contracts for the successful implementation of specific activities.

## ARTICLE 4. Confidentiality:
1. Commitment to use the provided information exclusively within the framework of this Memorandum, ensuring confidentiality and protection against unauthorized access by third Parties.
2. Strict adherence to the confidentiality regime during joint research and activities.

## ARTICLE 5. Financial Responsibility:
Any financial expenses arising from the support provided under this MOU shall be borne by the Contracting Parties requesting services unless otherwise agreed.

## ARTICLE 6. Settlement of Disputes:
Any dispute that might arise from the application and/or interpretation of this MOU shall be settled amicably between Contracting Parties by diplomatic channels and through consultations or negotiations.

## ARTICLE 7. Entry into Force:
1. This MOU shall enter into force on the date of the receipt of the last written notification through diplomatic channels by which the Contracting Parties notify each other of the completion of their internal procedures required for its entry into force.
2. This MOU may be amended by the mutual written consent of both Contracting Parties at any time. The amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedure prescribed in the first paragraph of this Article.
3. This MOU shall remain in force for a period of 3 years from the date of its entry into force and shall be renewed automatically for similar period or periods, unless one of the Contracting Parties notifies the other in writing and through diplomatic channels, about its intention to terminate it 6 months before its expiration date.
4. The termination of this MOU, shall not affect the validity or the duration of any specific agreements, projects and activities made under this MOU.

Done in Kuwait City in 3rd of November 2024, in Duplicate in Arabic, Tajiki and English languages. All texts being equally authentic. In case of divergence, the English text shall prevail.

# Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan on Cooperation in the Field of Standardization Activities

The Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>حكومة دولة الكويت</orig>, represented by the Public Authority for Industry <orig>الهيئة العامة للصناعة</orig> "Standards and Metrology Department <orig>إدارة المواصفات والمقاييس</orig>" (KOWSMD), and the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan <orig>حكومة جمهورية طاجيكستان</orig>, represented by the Agency for Standardization, Metrology, Certification and Trade Inspection <orig>وكالة المواصفات والمقاييس والشهادات والتفتيش التجاري</orig> (TAJIKSTANDARD), hereinafter referred to as "the Parties",
Desiring to enhance their cooperative relations in the field of standardization, quality, laboratories, and conformity assessment activities,
Seeking to ensure the quality of imported and exported industrial products (excluding food products), remove technical barriers to trade, and protect consumer safety between the two countries, while avoiding duplication in cross-border conformity assessments in accordance with international requirements,
Have agreed as follows:

## Article One
### Scope of Cooperation
To establish technical and scientific cooperation that achieves integration in the fields of standardization, technical regulations, inspection test results, and conformity assessment in a manner that serves their mutual interests.

## Article Two
### Areas of Cooperation
Cooperation between the Parties shall include their common areas of work with respect to:

**1. Standardization:**
a. Studying the possibility of adopting the standards in force in both countries whose references are international, European, regional, or Arab standards that do not conflict with the legislation of both countries.
b. Considering the standards issued by the Parties that are based on international references, for example: the International Organization for Standardization <orig>المنظمة الدولية للتقييس</orig> (ISO), as a primary reference when preparing standards in both countries.
c. The Parties shall identify the specifications and technical legislation related to the most traded goods between the two countries, specifying their reference and taking into account the following:
- For products for which unified specifications and technical legislation exist in both countries, the unified specifications and legislation between the two countries shall be adopted.
- For products for which non-unified specifications and technical legislation exist in both countries, the specifications or technical legislation adopted by the importing country shall be adopted.
d. Studying the possibility of harmonizing the specifications of products and goods subject to trade between the two countries in line with international standards (excluding food products).

**2. Conformity Assessment:**
a. Studying the mutual recognition of conformity assessment certificates issued by both Parties in accordance with the guides and documents of specialized international organizations and under a mechanism to be agreed upon between the Parties.
b. Studying the mutual recognition of inspection and test results issued by both Parties in accordance with the guides and documents of specialized international organizations, as well as the recognition of inspection and test results from laboratories accredited by both Parties.

**3. Laboratories:**
a. Participation in laboratory proficiency testing programs (PTP) and inter-laboratory comparisons (ILC).
b. Preparing special programs and studies for laboratories and testing methods in accordance with the requirements of international standards.

## Article Three
### Channels of Cooperation
Cooperation between the Parties shall be carried out as follows:
1. Exchanging experts and trainers and participating in training courses, seminars, conferences, and meetings related to the activities under this memorandum, which are held in either country.
